txt: Aleš Hrdlička, Czech-American anthropologist and scholar (d. 1943)

entities.title: Aleš Hrdlička
entities.description: Alois Ferdinand Hrdlička, after 1918 changed to Aleš Hrdlička, was a Czech anthropologist who lived in the United States after his family had moved there in 1881. He was born in Humpolec, Bohemia.

txt: Sir Edwin Lutyens, British architect (d. 1944)

entities.title: Pavlos Melas
entities.description: Pavlos Melas was an officer of the Hellenic Army, and was among the first who organized and participated in the Greek Struggle for Macedonia.

heading: Births
txt: Tom Hayward, English cricketer (d. 1939)

entities.title: Tom Hayward
entities.description: Thomas Walter Hayward was an English first-class cricketer who played for Surrey and England between the 1890s and the outbreak of World War I. He was primarily an opening batsman, noted especially for the quality of his off-drive. heading: Births
txt: Hal Colebatch, English-Australian politician, 12th Premier of Western Australia (d. 1953)

entities.title: Hal Colebatch
entities.description: Sir Harry Pateshall Colebatch CMG was a long-serving and occasionally controversial figure in Western Australian politics. He was a member of the Western Australian Legislative Council for nearly 20 years, the twelfth Premier of Western Australia for a month in 1919, agent-general in London for five years, and a federal senator for four years.

entities.title: Premier of Western Australia
entities.description: The Premier of Western Australia is the head of the executive branch of government in the Australian state of Western Australia. The Premier has similar functions in Western Australia to those performed by the Prime Minister of Australia at the national level, subject to the different Constitutions.

txt: Tullio Levi-Civita, Jewish-Italian mathematician and academic (d. 1941)

entities.title: Tullio Levi-Civita
entities.description: Tullio Levi-Civita, was an Italian mathematician, most famous for his work on absolute differential calculus and its applications to the theory of relativity, but who also made significant contributions in other areas. He was a pupil of Gregorio Ricci-Curbastro, the inventor of tensor calculus. His work included foundational papers in both pure and applied mathematics, celestial mechanics, analyti

heading: Births
txt: Lou Henry Hoover, American wife of Herbert Hoover, 33rd First Lady of the United States (d. 1944)

entities.title: Lou Henry Hoover
entities.description: Lou Hoover was the wife of President Herbert Hoover and served as the First Lady of the United States from 1929 to 1933.

entities.title: Herbert Hoover
entities.description: Herbert Clark Hoover was an American politician, businessman, and engineer who served as the 31st president of the United States from 1929 to 1933. A member of the Republican Party, he held office during the onset of the Great Depression. Before serving as president, Hoover led the Commission for Relief in Belgium, served as the director of the U.S. Food Administration, and served as the third U.S

entities.title: First Lady of the United States
entities.description: First Lady of the United States (FLOTUS) is the title held by the hostess of the White House, usually the wife of the president of the United States, concurrent with the president's term in office. Although the first lady's role has never been codified or officially defined, she figures prominently in the political and social life of the United States. Since the early 20th century, the first lady

heading: Births
txt: Friedrich Traun, German sprinter and tennis player (d. 1908)

entities.title: Friedrich Traun
entities.description: Friedrich Adolf Traun was a German athlete and tennis player. Born into a wealthy family, he participated in the 1896 Summer Olympics and won a gold medal in men's doubles. He committed suicide after being accused of fathering a child out of wedlock.

heading: Births
txt: Ed Archibald, Canadian pole vaulter (d. 1965)

entities.title: Edward Archibald (athlete)
entities.description: Edward Blake "Ed" Archibald was a Canadian athlete who competed mainly in the pole vault. He was born and died in Toronto.

heading: Births
txt: Dezső Kosztolányi, Hungarian author and poet (d. 1936)

entities.title: Dezső Kosztolányi
entities.description: Dezső Kosztolányi was a Hungarian writer, journalist, and translator. He wrote in all literary genres, from poetry to [(essays]] to theatre plays. Building his own style, he used French symbolism, impressionism, expressionism and psychological realism. He is considered the father of futurism in Hungarian literature.

heading: Births
txt: Enea Bossi, Sr., Italian-American engineer, designed the Budd BB-1 Pioneer and Bossi-Bonomi Pedaliante (d. 1963)

entities.title: Enea Bossi, Sr.
entities.description: Enea Bossi Sr. was an Italian-American aerospace engineer and aviation pioneer. He is best known for designing the Budd BB-1 Pioneer, the first stainless steel aircraft; and also the Pedaliante airplane, disputably credited with the first fully human-powered flight.

entities.title: Budd BB-1 Pioneer
entities.description: The Budd BB-1 Pioneer was an experimental United States flying boat of the 1930s utilizing the Savoia-Marchetti S.56 design. Its framework was constructed entirely of stainless steel, using a newly patented method of welding that alloy.

entities.title: Bossi-Bonomi Pedaliante
entities.description: The Pedaliante was a human-powered aircraft designed and built by Enea Bossi and Vittorio Bonomi and credited with, in 1936, making one of the first fully human-powered flights. The aircraft successfully traveled 1 km (0.62 mi) as part of an Italian competition, but was denied the monetary prize due to its catapult launch.

heading: Births
txt: Warner Baxter, American actor (d. 1951)

entities.title: Warner Baxter
entities.description: Warner Leroy Baxter was an American film actor from the 1910s to the 1940s. Baxter is known for his role as the Cisco Kid in the 1928 film In Old Arizona, for which he won the Academy Award for Best Actor at the 2nd Academy Awards. He frequently played womanizing, charismatic Latin bandit types in Westerns, and played the Cisco Kid or a similar character throughout the 1930s, but had a range of ot

heading: Births

heading: Births
txt: Bert Bliss, English international footballer (d. 1968)

entities.title: Bert Bliss
entities.description: Herbert Bliss was an English footballer who played for Tottenham Hotspur, Clapton Orient and England. He was born in Willenhall, Staffordshire.

heading: Births
txt: Yvan Goll, French-German poet and playwright (d. 1950)

entities.title: Yvan Goll
entities.description: Yvan Goll was a French-German poet who was bilingual and wrote in both French and German. He had close ties to both German expressionism and to French surrealism.

József Mindszenty [jo:ʒɛf mindsɛnti] was the Prince Primate, Archbishop of Esztergom, cardinal, and leader of the Catholic Church in Hungary from 2 October 1945 to 18 December 1973. According to Encyclopædia Britannica, for five decades "he personified uncompromising opposition to fascism and communism in Hungary". During World War II, he was imprisoned by the pro-Nazi Arrow Cross Party. 
After th

heading: Births
txt: Astrid Holm, Danish actress (d. 1961)

entities.title: Astrid Holm
entities.description: Astrid Holm was a Danish theater and film actress whose career began on the stage and in the early silent film era.

entities.title: Ernst Jünger
entities.description: Ernst Jünger was a philosopher, a highly decorated Imperial German soldier, author, and entomologist who became publicly known for his World War I memoir Storm of Steel.

heading: Births
txt: Wilhelm Ackermann, German mathematician (d. 1962)

entities.title: Wilhelm Ackermann
entities.description: Wilhelm Friedrich Ackermann was a German mathematician best known for the Ackermann function, an important example in the theory of computation.

heading: Births
txt: Lavrentiy Beria, Georgian-Russian general and politician (d. 1953)

entities.title: Lavrentiy Beria
entities.description: Lavrentiy Pavlovich Beria was a Georgian Bolshevik and Soviet politician, Marshal of the Soviet Union and state security administrator, chief of the Soviet security, and chief of the People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs (NKVD) under Joseph Stalin during World War II, and promoted to deputy premier under Stalin from 1941. He later officially joined the Politburo in 1946.

heading: Births
txt: Bill Aston, English race car driver (d. 1974)

entities.title: Bill Aston
entities.description: William Aston was a British racing driver who participated in three World Championship Grands Prix, in 1952 when the championship was run to Formula Two rules, for his own team Aston Butterworth.

heading: Births
txt: John McEwen, Australian farmer and politician, 18th Prime Minister of Australia (d. 1980)

entities.title: Prime Minister of Australia
entities.description: The prime minister of Australia is the head of government of Australia. The prime minister is the leader of the federal government and is also accountable to federal parliament under the principles of responsible government. The incumbent prime minister is Scott Morrison, who took office in August 2018 as leader of the Liberal Party.

entities.title: Minister of National Defence (Canada)

entities.title: James Bausch
entities.description: James Aloysius Bernard Bausch, also known as "Jarring Jim", was an American athlete who competed mainly in the decathlon.

He made his final film appearance in The Hiding Place (1975), portraying a watch-maker who hides Jews during World War II. O'Connell bore a physical resemblance to actor Jack Albertson. entities.description: Aubrey Wilson Mullican, known professionally as Moon Mullican and nicknamed "King of the Hillbilly Piano Players", was an American country and western singer, songwriter, and pianist. He was associated with the hillbilly boogie style which greatly influenced rockabilly. Jerry Lee Lewis cited him as a major influence on his own singing and piano playing.

heading: Births
txt: Hanna Reitsch, German soldier and pilot (d. 1979)

entities.title: Hanna Reitsch
entities.description: Hanna Reitsch was a German aviator and test pilot. Along with Melitta von Stauffenberg, she flight tested many of Germany's new aircraft during World War II and received many honors.

He hit over .300 lifetime (.302) and every year from 1944 through 1948, peaking with a .352 mark in 1945 when he finished second in the National League batting race and was runner-up for the NL's Most Valuable Player Award.

entities.title: Pearl Bailey
entities.description: Pearl Mae Bailey was an American actress and singer. After appearing in vaudeville she made her Broadway debut in St. Louis Woman in 1946. She won a Tony Award for the title role in the all-Black production of Hello, Dolly! in 1968. In 1986, she won a Daytime Emmy award for her performance as a fairy godmother in the ABC Afterschool Special Cindy Eller: A Modern Fairy Tale.

He was the son of William Henry Belk, who founded the first Belk store in Monroe, N.C., in 1888.

txt: Emperor Wu of Han of China (b. 157 BC)

entities.title: Emperor Wu of Han
entities.description: Emperor Wu of Han, formally enshrined as Emperor Wu the Filial, born Liu Che (劉徹) and courtesy name Tong (通), was the seventh emperor of the Han dynasty of ancient China, ruling from 141 to 87 BC. His reign lasted 54 years — a record not broken until the reign of the Kangxi Emperor more than 1,800 years later and remains the record for ethnic Chinese emperors. His reign resulted in a vast expansio

heading: Deaths
txt: Emperor Guangwu of Han (b. 5 BC)

entities.title: Emperor Guangwu of Han
entities.description: Emperor Guangwu, born Liu Xiu, courtesy name Wenshu, was an emperor of the Chinese Han dynasty, restorer of the dynasty in AD 25 and thus founder of the Later Han or Eastern Han. He ruled over parts of China at first, and through suppression and conquest of regional warlords, the whole of China was consolidated by the time of his death in AD 57.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gwynllyw, Welsh king and religious figure

entities.title: Gwynllyw
entities.description: Gwynllyw Filwr or Gwynllyw Farfog, known in English in a corrupted form as Woolos the Warrior or Woolos the Bearded was a Welsh king and religious figure.

heading: Deaths
txt: Pope Stephen IX (b. 1020)

entities.title: Pope Stephen IX
entities.description: Pope Stephen IX was the head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 3 August 1057 to his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ottokar I of Styria, German noble

entities.title: Ottokar I of Styria
entities.description: Ottokar I, also Otakar was count in the Bavarian Chiemgau and Margrave of Styria from 1056 until his death. He became progenitor of the dynasty of the Otakars.

heading: Deaths
txt: Emperor Go-Murakami of Japan (b. 1328)

entities.title: Emperor Go-Murakami
entities.description: Emperor Go-Murakami  was the 97th emperor of Japan, according to the traditional order of succession, and a member of the Southern Court during the Nanboku-chō period of rival courts. He reigned from September 18, 1339, until March 29, 1368. His personal name was Noriyoshi (義良). He reigned from Sumiyoshi, Ōsaka, Yoshino, Nara, and other temporary locations.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Percy, 3rd Earl of Northumberland, English politician (b. 1421)

entities.title: Henry Percy, 3rd Earl of Northumberland
entities.description: Henry Percy, 3rd Earl of Northumberland, was an English magnate.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lionel de Welles, 6th Baron Welles

heading: Deaths
txt: Matthew Palaiologos Asen, Byzantine aristocrat and official

entities.title: Matthew Palaiologos Asen
entities.description: Matthew Palaiologos Asen was a late Byzantine aristocrat and official, related to the Asen and Palaiologos dynasties.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis I, Cardinal of Guise (b. 1527)

entities.title: Louis I, Cardinal of Guise
entities.description: Louis de Lorraine was the fourth son of Claude, Duke of Guise and Antoinette de Bourbon, and the younger brother of Charles of Guise, Cardinal of Lorraine, and Mary of Guise, queen consort of King James V of Scotland. He was the nephew of Cardinal Jean de Lorraine. He is sometimes known as the cardinal de Guise.

heading: Deaths
txt: Arthur Champernowne, English admiral and politician (b. 1524)

heading: Deaths
txt: Tobias Matthew, English archbishop and academic (b. 1546)

entities.title: Tobias Matthew
entities.description: Tobias Matthew, was an English nobleman and bishop who was President of St John's College, Oxford from 1572 to 1576, before being appointed Vice-Chancellor of Oxford University from 1579 to 1583, and Matthew would then become Dean of Durham from 1583 to 1595. All three positions, plus others, were appointed to Matthew by Elizabeth I. Eventually, he was appointed Archbishop of York in 1606 by Eliza

heading: Deaths
txt: Jacob de Gheyn II, Dutch painter and engraver (b. 1565)

entities.title: Jacob de Gheyn II
entities.description: Jacob de Gheyn II was a Dutch painter and engraver, whose work shows the transition from Northern Mannerism to Dutch realism over the course of his career.

heading: Deaths
txt: Nicolaus Bruhns, Danish-German organist, violinist, and composer (b. 1665)

entities.title: Nicolaus Bruhns
entities.description: Nicolaus Bruhns was a Danish-German organist, violinist, and composer. He was one of the most prominent organists and composers of his generation.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Frederick II, Margrave of Brandenburg-Ansbach, (b. 1678)

entities.title: George Frederick II, Margrave of Brandenburg-Ansbach
entities.description: George Frederick II, Margrave of Brandenburg-Ansbach, known as George Frederick the Younger, the third son of John Frederick, Margrave of Brandenburg-Ansbach by his first wife the Margravine Joanna Elisabeth of Baden-Durlach, succeeded his elder brother as Margrave of Ansbach in 1692.

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Coram, English captain and philanthropist, founded Foundling Hospital (b. 1668)

entities.title: Thomas Coram
entities.description: Captain Thomas Coram was a philanthropist who created the London Foundling Hospital in Lamb's Conduit Fields, Bloomsbury, to look after abandoned children. It is said to be the world's first incorporated charity.

entities.title: Foundling Hospital
entities.description: The Foundling Hospital in London, England, was founded in 1739 by the philanthropic sea captain Thomas Coram. It was a children's home established for the "education and maintenance of exposed and deserted young children." The word "hospital" was used in a more general sense than it is in the 21st century, simply indicating the institution's "hospitality" to those less fortunate. Nevertheless, one

heading: Deaths
txt: Emanuel Swedenborg, Swedish astronomer, philosopher, and theologian (b. 1688)

entities.title: Emanuel Swedenborg
entities.description: Emanuel Swedenborg was a Swedish pluralistic-Christian theologian, scientist, philosopher and mystic. He became best known for his book on the afterlife, Heaven and Hell (1758).

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Wesley, English missionary and poet (b. 1707)

entities.title: Charles Wesley
entities.description: Charles Wesley was an English leader of the Methodist movement, most widely known for writing over 6,500 hymns.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gustav III of Sweden (b. 1746)

entities.title: Gustav III of Sweden
entities.description: Gustav III, also called Gustavus III, was King of Sweden from 1771 until his assassination in 1792. He was the eldest son of Adolf Frederick, King of Sweden and Queen Louise Ulrika, and a first cousin of Empress Catherine the Great of Russia by reason of their common descent from Christian August of Holstein-Gottorp, Prince of Eutin, and his wife Albertina Frederica of Baden-Durlach.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marc René, marquis de Montalembert, French general and engineer (b. 1714)

entities.title: Marc René, marquis de Montalembert
entities.description: Marc René, marquis de Montalembert was a French military engineer and writer, known for his work on fortifications.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gottfried van Swieten, Dutch-Austrian librarian and diplomat (b. 1733)

entities.title: Gottfried van Swieten
entities.description: Gottfried Freiherr van Swieten was a Dutch-born Austrian diplomat, librarian, and government official who served the Holy Roman Empire during the 18th century. He was an enthusiastic amateur musician and is best remembered today as the patron of several great composers of the Classical era, including Joseph Haydn, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, and Ludwig van Beethoven.

heading: Deaths
txt: Johann Heinrich Voss, German poet, translator, and academic (b. 1751)

entities.title: Johann Heinrich Voss
entities.description: Johann Heinrich Voss was a German classicist and poet, known mostly for his translation of Homer's Odyssey (1781) and Iliad (1793) into German.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cornelio Saavedra, Argentinian general and politician (b. 1759)

entities.title: Cornelio Saavedra
entities.description: Cornelio Judas Tadeo de Saavedra y Rodríguez was a military officer and statesman from the Viceroyalty of the Río de la Plata. He was instrumental in the May Revolution, the first step of Argentina's independence from Spain, and was appointed president of the Primera Junta.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Jacob Astor, German-American businessman (b. 1763)

entities.title: John Jacob Astor
entities.description: John Jacob Astor was a German–American businessman, merchant, real estate mogul, and investor who made his fortune mainly in a fur trade monopoly, by smuggling opium into China, and by investing in real estate in or around New York City. He is known for being the first multi-millionaire businessman of the United States.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henri Druey, Swiss politician, 2nd President of the Swiss Confederation (b. 1799)

entities.title: Henri Druey
entities.description: Daniel-Henri Druey was a Swiss politician of the 19th century and a founding father of constitutional democracy and member of Free Democratic Party in Switzerland.

entities.title: List of Presidents of the Swiss Confederation
entities.description: Below is a list of presidents of the Swiss Confederation (1848–present). It presents the presiding member of the Federal Council, Switzerland's seven-member executive.

heading: Deaths
txt: Francesco Zantedeschi, Italian priest and physicist (b. 1797)

entities.title: Francesco Zantedeschi
entities.description: Francesco Zantedeschi was an Italian priest and physicist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Inazuma Raigorō, Japanese sumo wrestler, the 7th Yokozuna (b. 1802)

entities.title: Inazuma Raigorō
entities.description: Inazuma Raigorō  was a Japanese sumo wrestler from Awazaki, Hitachi Province. He was the sport's 7th yokozuna.

entities.title: Yokozuna (sumo)
entities.description: Makuuchi (幕内), or makunouchi (幕の内), is the top division of the six divisions of professional sumo. Its size is fixed at 42 wrestlers (rikishi), ordered into five ranks according to their ability as defined by their performance in previous tournaments.

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles-Valentin Alkan, French pianist and composer (b. 1813)

entities.title: Charles-Valentin Alkan
entities.description: Charles-Valentin Alkan was a French-Jewish composer and virtuoso pianist. At the height of his fame in the 1830s and 1840s he was, alongside his friends and colleagues Frédéric Chopin and Franz Liszt, among the leading pianists in Paris, a city in which he spent virtually his entire life.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Plankinton, American businessman and industrialist, also noted for philanthropy (b. 1820)

entities.title: John Plankinton
entities.description: John Plankinton was an American businessman. He is noted for expansive real estate developments in Milwaukee, including the luxurious Plankinton House Hotel designed as an upscale residence for the wealthy. He was involved with railroading and banking. The Plankinton Bank he developed became the leading bank of Milwaukee in his lifetime. He was involved in the development of the Milwaukee City Rai

heading: Deaths
txt: Georges Seurat, French painter (b. 1859)

heading: Deaths
txt: Cyrus K. Holliday, American businessman (b. 1826)

entities.title: Cyrus K. Holliday
entities.description: Colonel Cyrus Kurtz Holliday was an American railroad executive who was one of the founders of the township of Topeka, Kansas, in the mid 19th century; and was Adjutant General of Kansas during the American Civil War. The title Colonel, however, was honorary. He was the first president of the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway, as well as one of the railroad's directors for nearly 40 years, up

heading: Deaths
txt: William Plankinton, American businessman, industrialist and banker (b. 1843)

entities.title: William Plankinton
entities.description: William Plankinton was an American businessman, manufacturer, and industrialist. He followed in his father's footsteps in the meat packing and meat processing industry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Slava Raškaj, Croatian painter (b. 1878)

entities.title: Slava Raškaj
entities.description: Slava Raškaj was a Croatian painter, considered to be the greatest Croatian watercolorist of the late 19th and early 20th century. Deaf since birth, Raškaj was schooled in Vienna and Zagreb, where her mentor was the renowned Croatian painter Bela Čikoš Sesija. In the 1890s her works were exhibited around Europe, including at the 1900 Expo in Paris. In her twenties Raškaj was diagnosed with acute d

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexandre Guilmant, French organist and composer (b. 1837)

entities.title: Alexandre Guilmant
entities.description: Félix-Alexandre Guilmant was a French organist and composer. He was the organist of La Trinité from 1871 until 1901. A noted pedagogue, performer, and improviser, Guilmant helped found the Schola Cantorum de Paris. He was appointed as Professor of Organ at the Paris Conservatoire in 1896.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry Robertson Bowers, Scottish lieutenant and explorer (b. 1883)

entities.title: Henry Robertson Bowers
entities.description: Henry Robertson Bowers was one of Robert Falcon Scott's polar party on the ill-fated Terra Nova expedition of 1910–1913, all of whom died during their return from the South Pole.

txt: Robert Falcon Scott, English lieutenant and explorer (b. 1868)

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward Adrian Wilson, English physician and explorer (b. 1872)

heading: Deaths
txt: Charles Villiers Stanford, Irish composer and conductor (b. 1852)

entities.title: Charles Villiers Stanford
entities.description: Sir Charles Villiers Stanford was an Irish composer, music teacher, and conductor of the late Romantic era. Born to a well-off and highly musical family in Dublin, Stanford was educated at the University of Cambridge before studying music in Leipzig and Berlin. He was instrumental in raising the status of the Cambridge University Musical Society, attracting international stars to perform with it.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Hermann Kahn, German-American banker and philanthropist (b. 1867)

entities.title: Otto Hermann Kahn
entities.description: Otto Hermann Kahn was a German-born American investment banker, collector, philanthropist, and patron of the arts.

heading: Deaths
txt: Karol Szymanowski, Polish pianist and composer (b. 1882)

entities.title: Karol Szymanowski
entities.description: Karol Maciej Szymanowski was a Polish composer and pianist, the most celebrated Polish composer of the early 20th century. He is considered a member of the late 19th-/early 20th-century modernist movement Young Poland and widely viewed as one of the greatest Polish composers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander Obolensky, Russian-English rugby player and soldier (b. 1916)

entities.title: Alexander Obolensky
entities.description: Prince Alexander Sergeevich Obolensky was a Rurikid prince of Russian origin who became a naturalised Briton, having spent most of his life in England, and who went on to represent England in international rugby union. He was, and remains, popularly known as "The Flying Prince", "The Flying Slav", or simply as "Obo" to many sports fans.

heading: Deaths
txt: Harry Price, English parapsychologist and author (b. 1881)

entities.title: Harry Price
entities.description: Harry Price was a British psychic researcher and author, who gained public prominence for his investigations into psychical phenomena and his exposing fraudulent spiritualist mediums. He is best known for his well-publicized investigation of the purportedly haunted Borley Rectory in Essex, England.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joyce Cary, Anglo-Irish novelist (b. 1888)

entities.title: Joyce Cary
entities.description: Arthur Joyce Lunel Cary was an Anglo-Irish novelist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Barthélemy Boganda, African priest and politician, 1st Prime Minister of the Central African Republic (b. 1910)

entities.title: Barthélemy Boganda
entities.description: Barthélemy Boganda was the leading nationalist politician from what is now the Central African Republic. Boganda was active prior to his country's independence, during the period when the area, part of French Equatorial Africa, was administered by France under the name of Oubangui-Chari. He served as the first Prime Minister of the Central African Republic autonomous territory.

entities.title: List of heads of state of the Central African Republic and Central African Empire
entities.description: This article lists the heads of state of the Central African Republic. There have been seven heads of state of the Central African Republic and the Central African Empire since independence was obtained from the French on 13 August 1960. This list includes not only those persons who were sworn into office as President of the Central African Republic but also those who served as de facto heads of s

heading: Deaths
txt: Gaspard Fauteux, Canadian dentist and politician, 19th Lieutenant Governor of Quebec (b. 1898)

entities.title: Gaspard Fauteux
entities.description: Gaspard Fauteux, was a Canadian parliamentarian, Speaker of the House of Commons of Canada (1945–1949), and the 19th Lieutenant Governor of Quebec (1950–1958).

entities.title: Lieutenant Governor of Quebec
entities.description: The Lieutenant Governor of Quebec is the viceregal representative in Quebec of the Canadian monarch, Queen Elizabeth II, who operates distinctly within the province but is also shared equally with the ten other jurisdictions of Canada, as well as the other Commonwealth realms and any subdivisions thereof, and resides predominantly in her oldest realm, the United Kingdom. The Lieutenant Governor of

heading: Deaths
txt: August Rei, Estonian soldier, journalist, and politician, 12th Estonian Minister of Foreign Affairs (b. 1886)

entities.title: Estonian Minister of Foreign Affairs
entities.description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs is the senior minister at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the Estonian Government. The Minister is one of the most important members of the Estonian government, with responsibility for the relations between Estonia and foreign states.

heading: Deaths
txt: Anna Louise Strong, American journalist and author (b. 1885)

entities.title: Anna Louise Strong
entities.description: Anna Louise Strong was an American journalist and activist, best known for her reporting on and support for communist movements in the Soviet Union and the People's Republic of China. She wrote over 30 books and varied articles.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dhirendranath Datta, Pakistani lawyer and politician (b. 1886)

entities.title: Dhirendranath Datta
entities.description:
Dhirendranath Datta 
was a Bengali lawyer by profession who was also active in the politics of undivided Bengal in pre-partition India, and later in East Pakistan (1947–1971).

heading: Deaths
txt: J. Arthur Rank, English businessman, founded Rank Organisation (b. 1888)

entities.title: J. Arthur Rank
entities.description: Joseph Arthur Rank, 1st Baron Rank was a British industrialist who was head and founder of the Rank Organisation.

entities.title: Rank Organisation
entities.description: The Rank Organisation was a British entertainment conglomerate founded by industrialist J. Arthur Rank in April 1937. It quickly became the largest and most vertically integrated film company in the United Kingdom, owning production, distribution and exhibition facilities. It also diversified into the manufacture of radios, TVs and photocopiers. The company name lasted until February 1996, when th

heading: Deaths
txt: Mantovani, Italian-English conductor and composer (b. 1905)

entities.title: Mantovani
entities.description: Annunzio Paolo Mantovani, known mononymously as Mantovani, was an Anglo-Italian conductor, composer and light orchestra-styled entertainer with a cascading strings musical signature.

heading: Deaths
txt: Eric Williams, Trinidadian historian and politician, 1st Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago (b. 1911)

entities.title: Eric Williams
entities.description: Eric Eustace Williams is regarded as the "Father of the Nation" of Trinidad and Tobago, having led the then British Colony of Trinidad and Tobago to majority rule on 28 October 1956, to independence on 31 August 1962, and republicanism on 1 August 1976, leading an unbroken string of general elections victories with his political party, the People's National Movement, until his death in 1981. He w

entities.title: Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago
entities.description: The Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago is the head of the executive branch of government in the republic of Trinidad and Tobago.

heading: Deaths
txt: Walter Hallstein, German academic and politician, 1st President of the European Commission (b. 1901)

entities.title: Walter Hallstein
entities.description: Walter Hallstein was a German academic, diplomat and statesman who was the first President of the Commission of the European Economic Community and one of the founding fathers of the European Union.

entities.title: President of the European Commission
entities.description: The President of the European Commission is the head of the European Commission, the executive branch of the European Union. The President of the Commission leads a Cabinet of Commissioners, referred to as the College, collectively accountable to the European Parliament. The President is empowered to allocate portfolios amongst, reshuffle or dismiss Commissioners as necessary. The College directs

heading: Deaths
txt: Carl Orff, German composer and educator (b. 1895)

heading: Deaths
txt: Nathan Farragut Twining, American general (b. 1897)

heading: Deaths
txt: Luther Terry, American physician and academic, 9th Surgeon General of the United States (b. 1911)

entities.title: Luther Terry
entities.description: Luther Leonidas Terry was an American physician and public health official. He was appointed the ninth Surgeon General of the United States from 1961 to 1965, and is best known for his warnings against the dangers and the impact of tobacco use on health.

entities.title: Surgeon General of the United States
entities.description: The surgeon general of the United States is the operational head of the U.S. Public Health Service Commissioned Corps (PHSCC) and thus the leading spokesperson on matters of public health in the federal government of the United States. The Surgeon General's office and staff are known as the Office of the Surgeon General (OSG) which is housed within the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maurice Blackburn, Canadian composer and conductor (b. 1914)

entities.title: Maurice Blackburn (composer)
entities.description: Joseph Albert Maurice Blackburn was a Canadian composer, conductor, sound editor for film, and builder of string instruments. He is known for his soundtracks for animated film.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ted Kluszewski, American baseball player and coach (b. 1924)

heading: Deaths
txt: Guy Bourdin, French photographer (b. 1928)

entities.title: Guy Bourdin
entities.description: Guy Bourdin, was a French artist and fashion photographer known for his provocative images. From 1955, Bourdin worked mostly with Vogue as well as other publications including Harper's Bazaar. He shot ad campaigns for Chanel, Charles Jourdan, Pentax and Bloomingdale's.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Henreid, American actor (b. 1908)

entities.title: Paul Henreid
entities.description: Paul Henreid was an Austrian-British-American actor, director, producer, and writer. He is best remembered for two film roles: Victor Laszlo in Casablanca and Jerry Durrance in Now, Voyager, both released between 1942 and 1943.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Travers, English actor, director, and screenwriter (b. 1922)

entities.title: Bill Travers
entities.description: William Inglis Lindon Travers, known professionally as Bill Travers, was a British actor, screenwriter, director and animal rights activist. Prior to his show business career, he had served in the British army with Gurkha and special forces units.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mort Meskin, American illustrator (b. 1916)

entities.title: Mort Meskin
entities.description: Morton Meskin was an American comic book artist best known for his work in the 1940s Golden Age of Comic Books, well into the late-1950s and 1960s Silver Age.

heading: Deaths
txt: Terry Moore, American baseball player and coach (b. 1912)

heading: Deaths
txt: Frank Daniel, Czech-American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1926)

entities.title: Frank Daniel
entities.description: František "Frank" Daniel was a Czech-American screenwriter, film director and teacher. He is known for developing the sequence paradigm of screenwriting. He served as a dean of FAMU, American Film Institute and USC School of Cinema-Television. He was also an Artistic Director of Sundance Institute.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Goldsworthy, Canadian ice hockey player (b. 1944)

heading: Deaths
txt: Hans-Walter Eigenbrodt, German footballer and coach (b. 1935)

entities.title: Hans-Walter Eigenbrodt
entities.description: Hans-Walter Eigenbrodt was a German football player. The defender won with Eintracht Frankfurt the German championship in 1959 and reached with the club the legendary 1960 European Cup Final against Real Madrid.

heading: Deaths
txt: Gyula Zsengellér, Hungarian footballer (b. 1915)

entities.title: Gyula Zsengellér
entities.description: Gyula Zsengellér was a Hungarian footballer who played as a striker. A legend of Újpest FC, he is most famous for his part in taking the Hungarian national team to the 1938 World Cup Final. He was that tournament's second-highest scorer, behind Leonidas of Brazil.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joe Williams, American jazz singer (b. 1918)

heading: Deaths
txt: Helge Ingstad, Norwegian lawyer, academic, and explorer (b. 1899)

entities.title: Helge Ingstad
entities.description: Helge Marcus Ingstad was a Norwegian explorer. In 1960, after mapping some Norse settlements, Ingstad and his wife archaeologist Anne Stine Ingstad found remnants of a Viking settlement in L'Anse aux Meadows in the province of Newfoundland in Canada. They were thus the first to prove conclusively that the Icelandic/Greenlandic Norsemen such as Leif Erickson had found a way across the Atlantic Ocea

heading: Deaths
txt: John Lewis, American pianist and composer (b. 1920)

heading: Deaths
txt: Carlo Urbani, Italian physician and microbiologist (b. 1956)

entities.title: Carlo Urbani
entities.description: Carlo Urbani was an Italian physician and microbiologist and the first to identify severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) as probably a new and dangerously contagious viral disease, and his early warning to the World Health Organization (WHO) triggered a swift and global response credited with saving numerous lives. He shortly afterwards himself became infected and died.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lise de Baissac, Mauritian-born SOE agent, war hero (b. 1905)

entities.title: Lise de Baissac
entities.description: Lise Marie Jeanette de Baissac MBE CdeG, code names Odile and Marguerite, was born in Mauritius of French descent and British nationality. She was an agent of the United Kingdom's clandestine Special Operations Executive (SOE) organization in France during World War II. The purpose of SOE was to conduct espionage, sabotage, and reconnaissance in countries occupied by the Axis powers, especially Na

entities.title: Special Operations Executive
entities.description: The Special Operations Executive (SOE) was a secret British World War II organisation. It was officially formed on 22 July 1940 under Minister of Economic Warfare Hugh Dalton, from the amalgamation of three existing secret organisations. Its purpose was to conduct espionage, sabotage and reconnaissance in occupied Europe against the Axis powers, and to aid local resistance movements.

heading: Deaths
txt: Joel Feinberg, American philosopher and academic (b. 1926)

heading: Deaths
txt: Miltos Sachtouris, Greek poet and author (b. 1919)

entities.title: Miltos Sachtouris
entities.description: Miltos Sachtouris or Miltos Sahtouris was a Greek poet. He was a descendant of Georgios Sachtouris which had origins from Ydra island. When he was young he aborted his law studies to follow his real passion, poetry, and adopted the pen name Miltos Chrysanthis. Sachtouris then wrote his first poem, The Music Of My Islands, under his pen name, in 1941.

heading: Deaths
txt: Salvador Elizondo, Mexican author and poet (b. 1932)

entities.title: Salvador Elizondo

heading: Deaths

entities.description: Larry L'Estrange MBE was a British paratrooper and rugby player.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vladimir Fedotov, Russian footballer and manager (b. 1943)

entities.title: Vladimir Fedotov
entities.description: Vladimir Grigoryevich Fedotov was a Soviet football striker and manager who holds the all-time record of caps for CSKA Moscow. He was the son of famous Soviet football and ice hockey player Grigory Fedotov.

heading: Deaths
txt: Andy Hallett, American actor and singer (b. 1975)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ângelo de Sousa, Portuguese painter and sculptor (b. 1938)

entities.title: Ângelo de Sousa
entities.description: Ângelo César Cardoso de Sousa was a Portuguese painter, sculptor, draftsman and professor, better known for continuously experimenting new techniques in his works. He was seen as a scholar of light and colour who explored minimalism in new radical ways.

heading: Deaths
txt: Iakovos Kambanellis, Greek author, poet, playwright, and screenwriter (b. 1921)

heading: Deaths
txt: Pap Cheyassin Secka, Gambian lawyer and politician (b. 1942)

entities.title: Pap Cheyassin Secka
entities.description: Pap Cheyassin Secka or Pap Cheyassin Ousman Secka was a Gambian lawyer and politician. He was the minister of justice and the former Attorney General of the Gambia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Bill Jenkins, American race car driver and engineer (b. 1930)

txt: Reginald Gray, Irish-French painter (b. 1930)

entities.description: Reginald Gray was an Irish portrait artist. He studied at The National College of Art (1953) and then moved to London, becoming part of the School of London led by Francis Bacon, Lucian Freud and Frank Auerbach. heading: Deaths
txt: Brian Huggins, English-Canadian journalist and actor (b. 1931)

heading: Deaths
txt: Liu Kang, Chinese footballer and manager (b. 1961)

txt: Ralph Klein, Canadian journalist and politician, 12th Premier of Alberta (b. 1942)

entities.title: Premier of Alberta
entities.description: The premier of Alberta is the first minister for the Canadian province of Alberta, and the province's head of government. The current premier is Jason Kenney, leader of the United Conservative Party, who was sworn in on April 30, 2019.

heading: Deaths
txt: Art Phillips, Canadian businessman and politician, 32nd Mayor of Vancouver (b. 1930)

entities.title: Mayor of Vancouver
entities.description: The mayor of the City of Vancouver is the head and chief executive officer of Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, elected for a four-year term. The 40th and current officeholder is Kennedy Stewart since 2018.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marc Platt, American actor and dancer (b. 1913)

entities.title: Marc Platt (dancer)
entities.description: Marcel Emile Gaston LePlat, known professionally as Marc Platt, was an American ballet dancer, musical theatre performer, and actor. He was best known for his portrayal of Daniel Pontipee, one of the seven brothers in the film Seven Brides for Seven Brothers.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Delafield Cook, Australian-English painter (b. 1926)

entities.title: William Delafield Cook
entities.description: William Delafield Cook AM (1936–2015) was an Australian artist who was known for his photorealistic landscapes. He won a number of awards, including the Order of Australia.

txt: Gerry Hardstaff, English cricketer (b. 1940)

heading: Deaths
txt: Patty Duke, American actress (b. 1946)

entities.title: Patty Duke
entities.description: Anna Marie "Patty" Duke was an American actress and mental health advocate. Over the course of her acting career, she was the recipient of an Academy Award, two Golden Globe Awards, three Primetime Emmy Awards, and a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexei Alexeyevich Abrikosov, Russian physicist (b. 1928)

entities.title: Alexei Alexeyevich Abrikosov
entities.description: Alexei Alexeyevich Abrikosov was a Soviet, Russian and American theoretical physicist whose main contributions are in the field of condensed matter physics. He was the co-recipient of the 2003 Nobel Prize in Physics, with Vitaly Ginzburg and Anthony James Leggett, for theories about how matter can behave at extremely low temperatures.

heading: Deaths
txt: Agnès Varda, French film director (b. 1928)

entities.title: Agnès Varda
entities.description: Agnès Varda was a Belgian-born French film director, screenwriter, photographer, and artist. Her pioneering work was central to the development of the widely influential French New Wave film movement of the 1950s and 1960s. Her films focused on achieving documentary realism, addressing women's issues, and other social commentary, with a distinctive experimental style.
